items.content_html:
‰∏≠ÈäÄËÜ†ÂõäÂ§ßÊ®ì Nakagin Capsule Tower

1970-1972 Êó•Êú¨, Êù±‰∫¨ Tokyo, Japan

Located in the heart of Tokyo, Kurokawa Kisho’s Nakagin Capsule Tower housed 140 self-contained units. The small apartments were designed for short-term stays by people who worked in the urban centre while living in the suburbs, reflecting new trends in how people moved throughout the city. The capsules were marketed as additional office space, secondary residences, or simple sites to recharge near the workplace. The tower was one of the few buildings realised as part of the 1960s Japanese architectural movement known as Metabolism. The name of the movement was a biological metaphor for how architecture could be designed with the ability to evolve, accommodating growth and changing societal needs. Attached to a concrete core service tower, the Nakagin capsules could, in theory, be replaced, which would extend the overall lifespan of the building. However, the building fell into disrepair in the early 2000s.

Despite numerous attempts to save it, it was demolished in 2022. Some capsules were carefully restored and collected by museums around the world, such as Unit A806 at M+.

June 10th, 2025 / M+ / West Kowloon, Hong Kong

The small apartments were designed for short-term stays by people who worked in the urban centre while living in the suburbs, reflecting new trends in how people moved throughout the city. The capsules were marketed as additional office space, secondary residences, or simple sites to recharge near the workplace. The tower was one of the few buildings realised as part of the 1960s Japanese architectural movement known as Metabolism. items.content_html:
Region No. 43701-No. 43900 (1998) LED mounted on aluminium, circuitry

Miyajima Tatsuo born 1957, Japan works Ibaraki

Two hundred LED counters flash numbers between 1 and 99 in red and green in endless loops. After reaching 99, the counter returns to 1. Numbers with the digit 0, a symbol of finality and emptiness for the artist, are omitted. The work may evoke affectless computer code but was in fact inspired by Miyajima’s experiences in the hospitals he frequented as a chronically ill child. The continual flashing and counting of numbers illustrate the Buddhist concept of samsara, the ceaseless cycle of reincarnation.

June 10, 2025 / M+ / West Kowloon, Hong Kong
items.content_text: Region No. 43701-No. 43900 (1998) LED mounted on aluminium, circuitry Miyajima Tatsuo born 1957, Japan works Ibaraki Two hundred LED counters flash numbers between 1 and 99 in red and green in endless loops. After reaching 99, the counter returns to 1. Numbers with the digit 0, a symbol of finality and emptiness for the artist, are omitted. The work may evoke affectless computer code but was in fact inspired by Miyajima's experiences in the hospitals he frequented as a chronically ill child. The continual flashing and counting of numbers illustrate the Buddhist concept of samsara, the ceaseless cycle of reincarnation. _June 10, 2025 / M+ / West Kowloon, Hong Kong_

items.content_html:
1234 (2008) single-channel digital video (colour, sound) 3 min. 33 sec. M+ Sigg Collection, Hong Kong. By donation

Zhou Tao born 1976, Hunan works Guangzhou

This work comprises photographs of morning staff assemblies at over forty shops in Chinese cities, including Shanghai and Shenzhen. During the assemblies, staff stand in military-like formation and recite chants. Zhou Tao edits and arranges the images according to the rhythm of the chants, showing how the collectivity of a socialist past has acquired a new function in the market economy as a highly effective governing tactic for modern corporations.

June 10, 2025 / M+ / West Kowloon, Hong Kong

items.content_html: morning donation run to Nights on the Street - Catholic Worker! seems to be a really good org in Berkeley-they’re out (usually just JC or JC and someone) on Kittredge and Shattuck in their champagne toyota (sienna?) every M-Sa from 6:30am-9am, handing out sleeping bags and other supplies, helping w/ mail service, and just being there for the unhoused. i had 3 sleeping bags, a twin-sized thicker mattress topper, and some pillows (all clean ofc) that i’m now able to know it’ll be put into good use, rather than end up at a landfill or otherwise be unaccessible by those who need it most.
items.content_text: morning donation run to [Nights on the Street - Catholic Worker](https://sites.google.com/site/berkeleycatholicworker/home)! seems to be a really good org in Berkeley-they're out (usually just JC or JC and someone) on Kittredge and Shattuck in their champagne toyota (sienna?) every M-Sa from 6:30am-9am, handing out sleeping bags and other supplies, helping w/ mail service, and just being there for the unhoused. i had 3 sleeping bags, a twin-sized thicker mattress topper, and some pillows (all clean ofc) that i'm now able to know it'll be put into good use, rather than end up at a landfill or otherwise be unaccessible by those who need it most.

items.title: my wishlist :)
items.content_html:
likes

  • what would be good gifts though: jewelry and clothing (i don’t typically get much of this for myself, so quality/intentional pieces i’ll treasure forever), home decor things (similar to previous, i love quality/intentional stuff that encapsulates a bit of the gifter’s artistic preference + gifting intention), handmade stuff… honestly i see a common trend already (intentional, tactile, and aesthetically grounded objects that carry meaning, not clutter)
  • tidbit on stationary: i have too, too, too much T.T
  • oooo books!!! the books i usually carry/like are sci-fi, cooking, and personal interests: interior design, architecture, tiny homes, japanese minimalism, etc. but im always open to more!
  • your time + thoughtfulness is honestly the greatest gift. it’s not easy and convenient, and i genuinely understand, which is why i truly truly appreciate it <3

caution

  • cheap, thoughtless gifts: i’ve received like really bad half-minded gifts that looked like they’re from knockoff amazon, i would 100% appreciate thoughtful card or some of your time over coffee/tea over that. i hate contributing to global waste by having to toss junk out. like as much as i want to say i appreciate the sentiment, i really don’t think there’s much sentiment behind these kinds of gifts

specific wishes:

  • supernote a5x2 + pen (~$600) + leather case for it (~$60) + (optional) booklight
  • e-ink frontlight 300+ppi ereader like boox note air, kindle scribe, kobo :D
  • vinyls!!! (japanese city pop, soft alt rnb like joji/keshi, arctic monkeys, not sure what else rn)
  • meta ray-ban glasses gen 3 (~$300) it’s not out yet though, gen 1 and 2 are out, but 3 should come late 2025 or early 2026!!

thank you’s:

  • may 2025 (to myself): thank you past self for getting me my long-awaited bleu de chauffe postman bag √©clair + sewing on a super cute leather lycoris recoil patch
  • february 2025 (to gabi and myself): thank you past self for negotiating a $200 deal on a pair of super lightly-used sony xm5s, then having gabi steal the deal behind my back and give it to me?? LOL
  • june 2024 (to myself): thank you for the updated timbuk2 authority laptop backpack deluxe! needed the upgrade + luggage passthrough for travels :)

**likes**
- what would be good gifts though: jewelry and clothing (i don't typically get much of this for myself, so quality/intentional pieces i'll treasure forever), home decor things (similar to previous, i love quality/intentional stuff that encapsulates a bit of the gifter's artistic preference + gifting intention), handmade stuff... honestly i see a common trend already (intentional, tactile, and aesthetically grounded objects that carry meaning, not clutter)
- tidbit on stationary: i have too, too, too much T.T
- oooo books!!! the books i usually carry/like are sci-fi, cooking, and personal interests: interior design, architecture, tiny homes, japanese minimalism, etc. but im always open to more!
- your time + thoughtfulness is honestly the greatest gift. it's not easy and convenient, and i genuinely understand, which is why i truly truly appreciate it <3 

**caution**
- cheap, thoughtless gifts: i've received like really bad half-minded gifts that looked like they're from knockoff amazon, i would 100% appreciate thoughtful card or some of your time over coffee/tea over that. i hate contributing to global waste by having to toss junk out. like as much as i want to say i appreciate the sentiment, i really don't think there's much sentiment behind these kinds of gifts

**specific wishes:**
- [supernote a5x2 + pen](https://supernote.com/products/supernote-a5-x2-manta) (~$600) + [leather case for it](https://www.etsy.com/listing/1439260705/handcrafted-rugged-leather-folio-cover) (~$60) + (optional) [booklight](https://a.co/d/aE1CPCF)
- e-ink frontlight 300+ppi ereader like boox note air, kindle scribe, kobo :D
- vinyls!!! (japanese city pop, soft alt rnb like joji/keshi, arctic monkeys, not sure what else rn)
- [meta ray-ban glasses gen 3](https://www.meta.com/ai-glasses/) (~$300) it's not out yet though, gen 1 and 2 are out, but 3 should come late 2025 or early 2026!! 

**thank you's:**
- may 2025 (to myself): thank you past self for getting me my long-awaited [bleu de chauffe postman bag √©clair](https://www.bleu-de-chauffe.com/en/mailman-bag/273-sac-postier-eclair-marinepain-brule-3700716002646.html) + sewing on a super cute leather [lycoris recoil patch](https://unlimitedpatchworks.com/products/lycoris-recoil-leather-velcro-patch)
- february 2025 (to gabi and myself): thank you past self for negotiating a $200 deal on a pair of super lightly-used sony xm5s, then having gabi steal the deal behind my back and give it to me?? LOL 
- june 2024 (to myself): thank you for the updated timbuk2 authority laptop backpack deluxe! needed the upgrade + luggage passthrough for travels :)

items.title: well... i just graduated
items.content_html:
I feel like there’s a lot to unpack, yet I’m still in the same constantly-on mode as I was this whole semester. It’s hard for me to really think, like there’s some kind of invisible weight on the top of my head. I think I’ll wait until later this summer to slowly let out some thoughts.

Just wanted to at least put an update out, especially since I’m not doing really anything at this particular minute.

This past week, though, has been hectic. Had to:

  • Take over repairs and maintenance for the condo I grew up in as parents have long been pretty mid + unbothered landlords and neglecting some much needed work: talked quotes, soothed frustrated residents, negotiated w/ contractors, coordinated HOA for water shut-offs, trying to figure out whether I’m getting a fair price or not, ensuring contract was somewhat bullet-resistant, taking initiative w/ gestures of goodwill, and just constant CALLS, CALLS, CALLS. However, the work should finish up tomorrow or the day after, which will hopefully offer some much-needed reprieve. Not sure if I’ll write up something about this, but tl;dr is old type-m cheap copper pipes, pinhole leaks -> water damage, doing full repipe w/ PEX-A + adaptors, issues w/ sharing lines, + drywall restoration.
  • Help w/ my mom’s car repairs. Was making a pretty bad noise + driving poorly. I advised her to go to a trusted local/independent mechanic rather than a dealership, and I even sent a few over to her that I vetted. She ended up at the dealership, but luckily, it was a pretty reasonably-priced inspection, and I was able to convince her to take the repairs at a trusted mechanic, which saved over $1000 overall. There could’ve been a few upsells like air filters, but honestly well-priced ones, so why not. They might’ve genuinely needed a change + it’s not like my parents would change those themselves. Win-win in my books. They get a bit more business + we get good prices on the larger repairs like changing the brake rotors and pads that she wore down.
  • Follow up on my two student’s college things, which I need to do later today as well, as they’re not staying on top of registration and other tasks despite promises to do so. I love working with them, but goodness it’s frustrating because I can’t be there for them all the time.
  • Catching up with United work: set up laptop for better access to Foundry + heads down/deep work. Lots and lots to do and figure out, sighs.
  • Parents came over for general commencement + broke the PS5 and showerhead within the 20 hours they stayed at the house, so had to get those repaired. Shopped around for PS5 hdmi repair quotes (ranged from $150-180) and found this goated shop that gave me a student discount to total $88 after taxes. Shoutout Quickfix Wireless on Telegraph. Evan (LL and roommate) handled the showerhead, ty.
  • Packing + moving + parents + graduation + social + dinners/chats w/ ppl’s parents + all of that. Not really stressful like the rest, but rather the fun and freeing side of the week.
  • IPIRA + RDI, need to get a move on those.
  • Final grades are rolling out. One professor mixed me up with another “Chen” and gave me a B instead of an A-. Actually had me so pmo for the last 24 hours, but he resolved it, thank goodness. Thought I needed to file a grade appeal or something for the first time in my college career because that was the most unwarranted B I ever gotten. In comparison, I’m happy to settle with an A-. After all, this professor is notorious with random grading that favors student athletes, finance bros/gals, and his inner circle of students. I, for one, am not part of that, but I did my fair share of the participation and work, so an A- is honestly quite reasonable. As for CS61C, I think I ended with a B+, which was better than my original hope for a B-, yet falls just short of an A-. Given I learned almost 75% of the course content in the two weeks leading up to the final. It’s a fair B+. Had I put in some effort into the class besides the bare minimum throughout the semester, I think I would have gotten an A-, although one could argue I wouldn’t have studied as hard as I did had I not been and justifiably felt so unprepared for the final. Seeing if I can clutch up an A-, but I think I’m, again, just short of the cut-off. Can’t have it all haha. Should be happy with what I have and how I did on the exam tbh. Went from -0.55 z-score to a positive one, which then clobbered the bad midterm performance.
  • Still tutoring, too :P

Anyways, a little psychological analysis if you don’t mind. Apparently, I’m (as well as many others for sure) in this state of cognitive fatigue and decision overload, a state where my prefrontal cortex (responsible for planning, focusing, and regulating emotions) is worn down from a long period of sustained mental effort. Like muscle fatigue, but for executive function. So, brain is genuinely exhausted. Additionally, chronic stress hormones are still being produced as our bodies have been running on cortisol and adrenaline for months, so that fight or flight is still basically on. Makes it hard to feel peace, rest, or process emotions. There’s also this psychological transition lag that psychologists call “liminal space” (an in-between zone after one identity ends (student) and before the next fully forms (adult/corporate cog/etc?). And apparently the brain dislikes this uncertainty and loss of structure, so it creates a weird emotional “buzz” where things can feel frozen or numb. Last concept would be the rest paradox, where rest after being in the hustle mode long enough can feel quite uncomfortable and even stressful as my brain associates idleness with being “unproductive” so it keeps scanning for tasks, making it hard to decompress. However, it’s right though as I do have a lot of tasks still, even after graduating, which I find ridiculous T.T let me travel and relax already.

All of it should pass with time as the nervous system rebalances and I actually finish some of the tasks on my plate :)

‚ÄúRest is not idleness, and to lie sometimes on the grass under trees on a summer’s day, listening to the murmur of the water, or watching the clouds float across the sky, is by no means a waste of time.‚Äù ‚Äï John Lubbock, The Use Of Life

Went from -0.55 z-score to a positive one, which then clobbered the bad midterm performance.

Apparently, I'm (as well as many others for sure) in this state of cognitive fatigue and decision overload, a state where my prefrontal cortex (responsible for planning, focusing, and regulating emotions) is worn down from a long period of sustained mental effort. Like muscle fatigue, but for executive function. So, brain is genuinely exhausted. Additionally, chronic stress hormones are still being produced as our bodies have been running on cortisol and adrenaline for months, so that fight or flight is still basically on. Makes it hard to feel peace, rest, or process emotions. There's also this psychological transition lag that psychologists call "liminal space" (an in-between zone after one identity ends (student) and before the next fully forms (adult/corporate cog/etc?). And apparently the brain dislikes this uncertainty and loss of structure, so it creates a weird emotional "buzz" where things can feel frozen or numb. items.content_html:
just studying for cs61c, going to be a really tough final; perhaps the toughest in my undergrad career simply due to the lack of preparation, discipline, and prioritization

reaping what i sow… it’s genuinely such an interesting class, but just have a sizable amount on my plate the entire semester, sighs. however, now on lecture 38, guest speaker Dave Patterson from Google and UC Berkeley

lessons from the first 50 years of my career

People

  1. Family first! Don‚Äôt sacrifice your family‚Äôs happiness on the altar of success.
  2. Choose happiness.
  3. It‚Äôs the people, not the projects, that you value in the long run.
  4. The cost of praise is small. The value to others is inestimable.
  5. Seek out honest feedback; it might be right.
  6. ‚ÄúFor better or for worse, benchmarks shape a field.‚Äù
  7. ‚ÄúI learned that courage was not the absence of fear, but the triumph over it.‚Äù
  8. Beware of those who believe that they are the smartest person in the room.

Career

  1. ‚ÄúMost of us spend too much time on what is urgent and not enough time on what is important.‚Äù
  2. ‚ÄúNothing great in the world has ever been accomplished without passion.‚Äù
  3. ‚ÄúThere are no losers on a winning team, and no winners on a losing team.‚Äù
  4. Lead by example.
  5. ‚ÄúAudentes Fortuna iuvat.‚Äù (Fortune favors the bold).
  6. Culture matters.
  7. It‚Äôs not how many projects you start; it‚Äôs how many you finish.
  8. Look for the positive opportunities.

here’s the presentation url saved in my drive. it’s really nothing more than what’s written above, but it’s a nice ppt format: [drive.google.com/file/d/1g…
items.content_text:
just studying for cs61c, going to be a really tough final; perhaps the toughest in my undergrad career simply due to the lack of preparation, discipline, and prioritization

reaping what i sow... it's genuinely such an interesting class, but just have a sizable amount on my plate the entire semester, sighs. however, now on lecture 38, guest speaker Dave Patterson from Google and UC Berkeley

**lessons from the first 50 years of my career**

People
1. Family first! Don‚Äôt sacrifice your family‚Äôs happiness on the altar of success.
2. Choose happiness.
3. It‚Äôs the people, not the projects, that you value in the long run.
4. The cost of praise is small. The value to others is inestimable.
5. Seek out honest feedback; it might be right.
6. ‚ÄúFor better or for worse, benchmarks shape a field.‚Äù
7. ‚ÄúI learned that courage was not the absence of fear, but the triumph over it.‚Äù
8. Beware of those who believe that they are the smartest person in the room.

Career
1. ‚ÄúMost of us spend too much time on what is urgent and not enough time on what is important.‚Äù
2. ‚ÄúNothing great in the world has ever been accomplished without passion.‚Äù
3. ‚ÄúThere are no losers on a winning team, and no winners on a losing team.‚Äù
4. Lead by example.
5. ‚ÄúAudentes Fortuna iuvat.‚Äù (Fortune favors the bold).
6. Culture matters.
7. It‚Äôs not how many projects you start; it‚Äôs how many you finish.
8. Look for the positive opportunities.

here's the presentation url saved in my drive. it's really nothing more than what's written above, but it's a nice ppt format: [[drive.google.com/file/d/1g...](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1guYFxcdx-GnJ9vlJWpJtASMkPNp-BwYM/view?usp=drive_link](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1guYFxcdx-GnJ9vlJWpJtASMkPNp-BwYM/view?usp=drive_link))

items.content_html:
Still struggling w/ passing California smog with my Miata. The P0012 code is quite sticky, and I’ve spent over $300 to date trying to resolve it. I just applied for the BAR CAP (Consumer Assistance Program) to get some money towards further repairs like looking at the timing belt + gears. Hopefully, they’ll get back to me with an approval within 2 weeks. Overall, though, really exhausted + disappointed I wasn’t able to find a way to pass smog today. Even drove highways to try to set all the monitors, but ended up just setting the CEL before the monitors were ready.

On the bright side, got Boichik bagels, fruits, and veggies today!

Hopefully, they'll get back to me with an approval within 2 weeks. Overall, though, really exhausted + disappointed I wasn't able to find a way to pass smog today. Even drove highways to try to set all the monitors, but ended up just setting the CEL before the monitors were ready. On the bright side, got Boichik bagels, fruits, and veggies today!

items.content_html:
Saw this random tweet on Instagram, who knows if it’s true and it doesn’t really matter to me either. Basically, the question was: can somebody explain the logic of waiting until you have the red to cross the street?

A person said: When my mother first moved to Japan, she tried to jaywalk while pushing a stroller on an empty residential street. She was immediately stopped by an old, well-dressed Japanese man who solemnly told her in perfect English “the downfall of society begins with the individual”

There’s a lot of truth to that statement, yet I find some of the pushback quite relatable, like the frustration of a world increasingly dominated by cars. Collectivism and individualism is also a key conflict. As much as I like individualism to whatever extent my understanding is, it saddens me to see the lack of unity and collectivism in my country. But, back to the topic at hand, jaywalking is fine in many instances. There’s a lot of empty streets in Japan that locals still wait for the green light for. There’s also a lot of empty streets in which they don’t wait for the light. I think there’s a few factors that come into play with that decision for locals. As for me, I just follow what the locals do tbh. If they wait, I’ll wait. If they don’t I don’t. However, I agree that streets should be for the people. The way we move around the city should center around pedestrians first.

There’s a lot more depth to this issue that I’m not covering, of course. Why do lights exist? Why is jaywalking considered bad? etc. This isn’t a fully flushed-out thought, just a random one. (rediscovered for myself a really iconic illustration below)

items.content_html: sorry to myself that I have been blogging much/tweeting much. super hectic end of sem. have so much to get done; slogging away it seems. took grad pics today! got mimi to mechanic to get her checked out for her check engine light. fingers crossed that works out. but rn, quite quite sick. head is awful. body is warm. throat feeling scratchy? just overall fatigued and unmotivated. terrible timing. had a volleyball skill assessment today to as like a PE class final, and after coming back home, I was basically out of commission for five hours. ggs. here‚Äôs a sneak pic of grad photos!

items.content_html:
I miss #yolo. I feel a bit cynical. The world seems to be falling apart bits by bits. We are so consumed by distractions. Online shopping. Influencers. Doom-scrolling. Grind and hustle culture. I think it’s just my mental tbh. Just working day in and day out. I just want to truly relax, but this semester ain’t it. It be like that though. I enrolled myself into responsibilities that are responsible for my workload. I just wish the rewards justified the sacrifice.

Okay, I’m just ranting because I’m a bit annoyed at something/someone. But, I’ll still rant. Like… no. We don’t need to work 80 hours a week to be happy. But, at the same time, why do I have to worry about finances? Why do I have to worry that I can’t afford a house? Why is it that we put others down in this world? Why is it that we refuse to grant adequate amounts of housing and construction? Why is it that we’d rather fund bombs than fund space programs? Why is it that our lives are so strongly influenced and controlled by the whims of the few? Why is it that your life is so strongly dependent on luck? Of course, you can make your own future. You can make your own fate. But, we didn’t choose to be born. We didn’t choose to toil the soil beneath our feet for the benefit of the mighty few. We didn’t choose to lose the few hours our lives offer to reap a scarce fraction of our blood, sweat, and tears. Sighs. End rant.

‚ÄúCivilization is a hopeless race to discover remedies for the evils it produces.‚Äù ‚Äî Jean-Jacques Rousseau

items.content_html:
just wrapped up our short visit to Miami! overall thoughts of the city

  • very car-dominant
  • didn‚Äôt get a chance to use public transit as uber/lyft was quite affordable and transit was expensive and was a bit inconvenient and slow (a 15-min drive often was a 50 minute transit)
  • quite terrible drivers
  • surprisingly expensive for food and activities, didn‚Äôt know it would be comparable to the Bay Area (lowkey more expensive)
  • seems rent is expensive for the level of income in the area asw
  • so so many yachts!!! and mega yachts!!!
  • even with attractions, mid-ass city for the middle to low income üò≠ ig anywhere is fun when you can afford a yacht
  • lots of nice cars, Porsches in particular
  • great Caribbean food fs

- great Caribbean food fs

items.content_html: finished All Quiet on the Western Front today for my NLP class. honestly really appreciated the excuse to read. it was nice not having to worry about not advancing my academic backlog of work and be able to enjoy a nice book. I have wondered oftentimes whether reading a book is similar to watching a tv show, especially if both are fiction. but having not truly read in a while, I can see the benefits of being exposed to more varied, thoughtful, intentional, and creative writing. what a shame that we’re transitioning into a world that no longer substantially rewards those who practice and master the art of writing. in high school, I longed to write as eloquently as the authors I was subjected to read. now, despite my understanding that effort spent is not wasted, it still feels like a waste to devote oneself to a skill so easily mimicked mindlessly. of course, it’s not 100% the same, but even 80% is a skill level largely attainable traditionally through trying practice and time. I can’t even begin to sympathize for artists and designers out there. of course, there are many that can take advantage of newer technologies to grow and succeed. perhaps this is simply another blip in the march of technological growth and its impact. but one can’t seem to pause and consider what might be lost in the process for our generations today.

items.content_html: been in chicago the past few days, enjoying it a lot. had a day with amazing weather. met up with lucy and her friends to celebrate her “unemployment” day. they were fun to chat with throughout the night. wicker park was pretty dope, although I do see a lot of locals complaining about its gentrification and sterile-ness at times. thinking of where i should live in chicago… though, the city itself has taken me again. it’s cleaner & more affordable than NYC. it’s cleaner & more affordable & livelier than SF. those are just my two cents and my own lived experiences and opinions. biking by the lakefront, though, just up gold coast, was just wonderful.

items.content_html:
completed my own tax returns via freetaxusa but sent the files to mom’s accountant to let him do his thing since my mom pays him a flat fee each year anyways (i wanted the practice of doing it myself, and now i can cross-check it). kinda annoying though since my income from illinois is flat-taxed, which disproportionately harms the lower-income (ahem, me)

postponing my jury duty service to post-graduation, but there are no dates to postpone to T.T hoping an agent picks up because I cannot go down to LA in two weeks just for this. edit: no one picked up but i was able to submit a transfer request to near Berkeley while on hold, so that should be fine for the time-being

continuing to sort out the Hertz insurance issue for my “aunt” this morning

now helping look into moving companies for evan & hashing out Divvy for Everyone for gabi

items.content_html:
there‚Äôs a Venezuelan food spot in Brickell that‚Äôs really good and well-priced! gave us some chicken soup on the house too üò≠ also gave Joe‚Äôs Stone Crab a go & it was good! for the ambience and history, the value is still quite good there‚Äî1/2 chicken for like $9 and lowkey I quite enjoyed the free bread (ate it before the camera did üíÄ). The hashbrowns were really good (but tbf I love hashbrowns), and I ordered a large after sampling some, and our waiter downgraded it to a half-size on his own accord and thank goodness he did üò≠ the half-size was very much more than enough for me alongside my other two dishes LOL (both of which I needed help finishing). Evan and Gabi said the crab is good and quite conveniently pre-cracked, but not like to die for, but solid. at the end, we were all very stuffed and satisfied.

El Sitio Coffee Bar 19 NE 2nd Ave, Miami, FL 33132

Joe‚Äôs Stone Crab 11 Washington Ave, Miami Beach, FL 33139

items.content_html: Vizcaya Village Farmers Market + Vizcaya Museums & Gardens were both successes! The farmer market had a lot of good & diverse food, and we had a bunch of empanadas as well as fresh Floridian orange juice and sugarcane juice. The museum and gardens was really pretty and was overall a fun time! Lots of lizards abound in Miami ü¶é

items.content_html: im in so much pain. my mom threw away my retainers on accident right when I started that part of the treatment, and the dental clinic had my pay $600 to replace it and also failed to inform me of when they arrived despite repeated left voicemails inquiring about it. so, only got the replacement a month later (today) AND THEY HURT SO MUCH. awfully painful. oh the misery üò≠ gloom despair agony depression ü´†

items.content_html: hmm‚Ä¶ midterms didn‚Äôt go great. in fact, quite probable it‚Äôs the worst performance in my Berkeley career. really not enough time this semester to do the things I need and want, which includes studying and genuinely being familiar with the material. it‚Äôs a shame really, the classes are interesting, but I have notably more responsibilities & also a heightened desire to enjoy life this semester than previous ones.

items.content_text: [www.app.traveltime.com](www.app.traveltime.com) is a dope tool to check reachable areas via given time of day / mode of transportation. using it right now to see what areas are reachable to work w/in 30 min!

items.content_html: www.hoodmaps.com is another really cool map, but it’s instead crowdsourced and vibe-based where people tag areas w/ stereotypes and local knowledge like “tech bros,” “warzone,” “run and don’t look back,” “smart college students,” etc. it’s more of like a social/cultural snapshot of how ppl percieve different neighborhoods.
items.content_text: [www.hoodmaps.com](www.hoodmaps.com) is another really cool map, but it's instead crowdsourced and vibe-based where people tag areas w/ stereotypes and local knowledge like "tech bros," "warzone," "run and don't look back," "smart college students," etc. it's more of like a social/cultural snapshot of how ppl percieve different neighborhoods.

items.content_html: www.opportunityatlas.org is a pretty cool website to look at how neighborhoods shape economic mobility/life outcomes. really interactive maps & full of research/data. honestly, pretty cool website to gauge where to move to and where certain demographics are living within a city/county.
items.content_text: [www.opportunityatlas.org](https://www.opportunityatlas.org/) is a pretty cool website to look at how neighborhoods shape economic mobility/life outcomes. really interactive maps & full of research/data. honestly, pretty cool website to gauge where to move to and where certain demographics are living within a city/county.

items.content_html:
I thought an assignment re. a DCF was due tonight, so I instead did comparable trading multiples instead due to time and I was like, I’m sorry!! I didn’t have time, but I did put in full effort for the comparables… it turns out it’s due tomorrow night… question is whether I should redo it and actually do a DCF and be like, whoops, I did have time… I’ll let tomorrow me decide since I have a midterm Wednesday morning. I feel as though I over-committed myself this semester, seems like I always have things to do and things due. Oh well.

update: did not re-do it bc of a competing priority, that being a midterm for another class, which I did post about (tl;dr: didn’t go well)

items.title: mimi aint passing smog check, pain
items.content_html:
ok why does everything cost money?

so went to get my smog checked, $30 regardless if pass or fail failed, obviously by the title, and it’s because error code P0012 - “A” Camshaft Position - Timing Over-Retarded Bank 1. just great because I diagnosed this issue months and months ago and found that it’s not only a common problem on the Miata NB, but also very hard to find the root cause…

ok so after an hour dooming and researching outside because I can’t sell my car without passing smog. I found the California CAP (consumer assistance program) which can help cover costs of repair up to X amount if I qualify. well I’m on CalFresh so I do, but it’s a joint ownership so I’m worried my mom will disqualify mimi for it. sighs.

anyways I went to a cafe to collect my thoughts bc the smog check place said it’d be $150 for diagnosis.

I called Fred’s Warehouse and didn’t really know what to say tbh. kinda out of my field of expertise. are they able to diagnose over the phone? is there even a point telling him my error code? like what?? anyways he was a bit stern but nice and straightforward, said that I should check my oil as a first measure since it can affect the camshaft position. that I knew but I guess I got overwhelmed by the tens and tens of other issues that could cause this error code on mimi. also he said $175 for diagnosis, pain.

so I was like okay, let’s oil change mimi myself bc I should learn anyways and I like doing DIY. but tell me why miata owners say the oil/filter the most inconveniently located place for NB?! also I don’t want to hurt myself, hurt the car, and have a mess to deal with like waste oil. so yeah, it was not worth my time right now as I’m a college student without much time nor tools. sooooo, looked at places to get my oil changed and I was like might as well get my leaking tire fixed.

so tires. I called DC Tires bc a AAA mechanic brought gabi and mimi there once to get a new tire and apparently a really good experience + good price. they were indeed nice and said they got nothing that old in stock, that being 24 years old model. fair. they recommended me to buy a tire online and they can switch it for me. as for oil change, they didn’t do it but referred me to an oil change shop, which would top off my other fluids, too. not sure what other fluids there are tbh. i know there are other fluids, but how good is that deal persay.

anyways, my smog test place also did oil changes and they were nice. $60 was their quote, but they told me to first check if I need a top-off or an oil change, and that I shouldn’t do an oil change if unnecessary. hence why I like that place in general, solid advice. so, I guess that’s the next step. something about a dipstick and oil level. sighs.

the nice reprieve is that all these places (DC, Fred’s, and 15min) seemed pretty helpful and considerate and gave me tips to move towards resolving the issues I brought up w/o necessarily trying to upsell me their services. for that, I am quite appreciative, esp. given the poor reputation the mechanic/car industry as a whole has in their treatment and exploitation of the uninformed and poor.

registration apparently expiring in two days, what to do. got an exam that day, too, which I’m behind on, so that takes priority. being broke is tough. but just fyi, at least in cali, I already paid the registration fee so I won’t get charged late fees, but when my tag expires in the two days, I can technically get pulled over and get fix-it tickets, which should be resolved once I, yk, fix the problem in question. impt thing is: avoid public parking. apparently u can just get parking tickets for incomplete registration, which is the case here. sighs.

“it is expensive to be poor” - james baldwin

items.title: starting microblogging
items.content_html:
first day of microblogging, not sure why I was so interested finding something like this, maybe just wanted to have a place to say things and look back‚Äîgot an exam soon, gotta lock in

btw joseph, don‚Äôt forget to think abt categories
